an6.16:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
an6.16:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an6.16:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nakulapitā gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
an6.16:1.2.eng: Now at that time the householder Nakula’s father was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

an6.16:1.3.pli: Atha kho nakulamātā gahapatānī nakulapitaraṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
an6.16:1.3.eng: Then the housewife Nakula’s mother said to him:

an6.16:2.3.eng: and it’s criticized by the Buddha.

an6.16:2.4.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:2.5.pli: ‘na nakulamātā gahapatānī mamaccayena sakkhissati dārake posetuṃ, gharāvāsaṃ santharitun’ti.
an6.16:2.5.eng: ‘When I’ve gone, the housewife Nakula’s mother won’t be able to provide for the children and keep up the household carpets.’

an6.16:2.6.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:2.6.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:2.7.pli: Kusalāhaṃ, gahapati, kappāsaṃ kantituṃ veṇiṃ olikhituṃ.
an6.16:2.7.eng: I’m skilled at spinning cotton and carding wool.

an6.16:2.8.pli: Sakkomahaṃ, gahapati, tavaccayena dārake posetuṃ, gharāvāsaṃ santharituṃ.
an6.16:2.8.eng: I’m able to provide for the children and keep up the household carpets.

an6.16:2.9.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:2.9.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns …

an6.16:3.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:3.2.eng: ‘When I’ve gone, the housewife Nakula’s mother will take another husband.’

an6.16:3.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:3.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:3.4.pli: Tvañceva kho, gahapati, jānāsi ahañca, yaṃ no soḷasavassāni gahaṭṭhakaṃ brahmacariyaṃ samāciṇṇaṃ.
an6.16:3.4.eng: Both you and I know that we have remained chaste while at home for the past sixteen years.

an6.16:3.5.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:3.5.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns …

an6.16:4.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:4.2.pli: ‘nakulamātā gahapatānī mamaccayena na dassanakāmā bhavissati bhagavato na dassanakāmā bhikkhusaṅghassā’ti.
an6.16:4.2.eng: ‘When I’ve gone, the housewife Nakula’s mother won’t want to see the Buddha and his Saṅgha of mendicants.’

an6.16:4.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:4.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:4.4.pli: Ahañhi, gahapati, tavaccayena dassanakāmatarā ceva bhavissāmi bhagavato, dassanakāmatarā ca bhikkhusaṅghassa.
an6.16:4.4.eng: When you’ve gone, I’ll want to see the Buddha and his mendicant Saṅgha even more.

an6.16:4.5.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:4.5.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns …

an6.16:5.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:5.2.eng: ‘The housewife Nakula’s mother won’t fulfill ethics.’

an6.16:5.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:5.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:5.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, tassa bhagavato sāvikā gihī odātavasanā sīlesu paripūrakāriniyo, ahaṃ tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:5.4.eng: I am one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who fulfills their ethics.

an6.16:5.5.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā—ayaṃ so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye—taṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchatu.
an6.16:5.5.eng: Whoever doubts this can go and ask the Buddha. He is staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an6.16:5.6.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:5.6.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns …

an6.16:6.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:6.2.eng: ‘The housewife Nakula’s mother doesn’t have internal serenity of heart.’

an6.16:6.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:6.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:6.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, tassa bhagavato sāvikā gihī odātavasanā lābhiniyo ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, ahaṃ tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:6.4.eng: I am one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who has internal serenity of heart.

an6.16:6.5.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā—ayaṃ so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye—taṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchatu.
an6.16:6.5.eng: Whoever doubts this can go and ask the Buddha. He is staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an6.16:6.6.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:6.6.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns …

an6.16:7.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

an6.16:7.2.pli: ‘na nakulamātā gahapatānī imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ogādhappattā patigādhappattā assāsappattā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane viharatī’ti.
an6.16:7.2.eng: ‘The housewife Nakula’s mother has not found a footing, a firm footing, and solace in this teaching and training. She has not gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and gained assurance. And she’s not independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.’

an6.16:7.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, gahapati, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an6.16:7.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

an6.16:7.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, tassa bhagavato sāvikā gihī odātavasanā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ogādhappattā patigādhappattā assāsappattā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane viharanti, ahaṃ tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:7.4.eng: I am one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who has found a footing, a firm footing, and solace in this teaching and training. I have gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and gained assurance. And I am independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.

an6.16:7.5.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā—ayaṃ so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye—taṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchatu.
an6.16:7.5.eng: Whoever doubts this can go and ask the Buddha. He is staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an6.16:7.6.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
an6.16:7.6.eng: So householder, don’t pass away with concerns.

an6.16:7.8.eng: and it’s criticized by the Buddha.”

an6.16:8.1.pli: Atha kho nakulapituno gahapatissa nakulamātarā gahapatāniyā iminā ovādena ovadiyamānassa so ābādho ṭhānaso paṭippassambhi.
an6.16:8.1.eng: And then, as Nakula’s mother was giving this advice to Nakula’s father, his illness died down on the spot.

an6.16:8.2.pli: Vuṭṭhahi ca nakulapitā gahapati tamhā ābādhā;
an6.16:8.2.eng: And that’s how Nakula’s father recovered from that illness.

an6.16:8.3.pli: tathā pahīno ca pana nakulapituno gahapatissa so ābādho ahosi.

an6.16:8.4.pli: Atha kho nakulapitā gahapati gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā daṇḍamolubbha yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nakulapitaraṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an6.16:8.4.eng: Soon after recovering, leaning on a staff he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an6.16:9.2.pli: Yassa te nakulamātā gahapatānī anukampikā atthakāmā ovādikā anusāsikā.
an6.16:9.2.eng: to have the housewife Nakula’s mother advise and instruct you out of kindness and sympathy.

an6.16:9.3.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, mama sāvikā gihī odātavasanā sīlesu paripūrakāriniyo, nakulamātā gahapatānī tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:9.3.eng: She is one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who fulfills their ethics.

an6.16:9.4.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, mama sāvikā gihī odātavasanā lābhiniyo ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, nakulamātā gahapatānī tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:9.4.eng: She is one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who has internal serenity of heart.

an6.16:9.5.pli: Yāvatā kho, gahapati, mama sāvikā gihī odātavasanā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ogādhappattā patigādhappattā assāsappattā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane viharanti, nakulamātā gahapatānī tāsaṃ aññatarā.
an6.16:9.5.eng: She is one of those white-robed disciples of the Buddha who has found a footing, a firm footing, and solace in this teaching and training. She has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and gained assurance. And she is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.

an6.16:9.6.pli: Lābhā te, gahapati, suladdhaṃ te, gahapati.
an6.16:9.6.eng: You’re fortunate, householder, so very fortunate,

an6.16:9.7.pli: Yassa te nakulamātā gahapatānī anukampikā atthakāmā ovādikā anusāsikā”ti.
an6.16:9.7.eng: to have the housewife Nakula’s mother advise and instruct you out of kindness and sympathy.”

an6.17:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an6.17:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an6.17:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an6.17:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, and sat down on the seat spread out.

an6.17:1.3.pli: Āyasmāpi kho sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an6.17:1.3.eng: Venerable Sāriputta also came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

an6.17:1.12.pli: āyasmāpi kho ānando sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

an6.17:1.13.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bahudeva rattiṃ nisajjāya vītināmetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
an6.17:1.13.eng: The Buddha spent much of the night sitting in meditation, then got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

an6.17:1.14.pli: Tepi kho āyasmanto acirapakkantassa bhagavato uṭṭhāyāsanā yathāvihāraṃ agamaṃsu.
an6.17:1.14.eng: And soon after the Buddha left those venerables each went to their own dwelling.

an6.17:1.15.pli: Ye pana tattha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ te yāva sūriyuggamanā kākacchamānā supiṃsu.
an6.17:1.15.eng: But those mendicants who were junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training slept until the sun came up, snoring.

an6.17:1.16.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena te bhikkhū yāva sūriyuggamanā kākacchamāne supante.
an6.17:1.16.eng: The Buddha saw them doing this, with his clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman.

an6.17:1.17.pli: Disvā yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an6.17:1.17.eng: He went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,

an6.17:2.11.pli: Kahaṃ nu kho te, bhikkhave, therā sāvakā gatā”ti?
an6.17:2.11.eng: Where have these senior disciples gone?”

an6.17:2.12.pli: “Tepi kho, bhante, āyasmanto acirapakkantassa bhagavato uṭṭhāyāsanā yathāvihāraṃ agamaṃsū”ti.
an6.17:2.12.eng: “Soon after the Buddha left those venerables each went to their own dwelling.”

an6.17:2.13.pli: “Tena no tumhe, bhikkhave, therā bhikkhū nāgatāti yāva sūriyuggamanā kākacchamānā supatha?
an6.17:2.13.eng: “So, mendicants, when the senior mendicants left, why did you sleep until the sun came up, snoring?

an6.17:2.15.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.17:2.15.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.17:2.16.pli: ‘rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharanto yāvajīvaṃ rajjaṃ kārento janapadassa vā piyo manāpo’”ti?
an6.17:2.16.eng: of an anointed aristocratic king who rules his whole life, dear and beloved to the country, while indulging in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing as much as he likes?”

an6.17:2.19.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.17:2.19.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.17:2.20.pli: ‘rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharanto yāvajīvaṃ rajjaṃ kārento janapadassa vā piyo manāpo’ti.

an6.17:3.2.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.17:3.2.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.17:3.7.pli: pūgagāmaṇiko yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharanto yāvajīvaṃ pūgagāmaṇikattaṃ kārento pūgassa vā piyo manāpo’”ti?
an6.17:3.7.eng: or a guild head who runs the guild his whole life, dear and beloved to the guild, while indulging in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing as much as he likes?”

an6.17:3.10.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.17:3.10.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.17:3.11.pli: ‘pūgagāmaṇiko yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharanto yāvajīvaṃ pūgagāmaṇikattaṃ vā kārento pūgassa vā piyo manāpo’ti.

an6.17:4.2.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.17:4.2.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.17:4.3.pli: ‘samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto indriyesu aguttadvāro bhojane amattaññū jāgariyaṃ ananuyutto avipassako kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pubbarattāpararattaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanānuyogaṃ ananuyutto āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanto’”ti?
an6.17:4.3.eng: of an ascetic or brahmin who indulges in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing as much as they like? Their sense doors are unguarded, they eat too much, they’re not dedicated to wakefulness, they’re unable to discern skillful qualities, and they don’t pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn. Yet they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

an6.17:4.6.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.17:4.6.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.17:4.7.pli: ‘samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yāvadatthaṃ seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto indriyesu aguttadvāro bhojane amattaññū jāgariyaṃ ananuyutto avipassako kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pubbarattāpararattaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanānuyogaṃ ananuyutto āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanto’ti.

an6.17:5.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an6.17:5.2.pli: ‘indriyesu guttadvārā bhavissāma, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṃ anuyuttā, vipassakā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ, pubbarattāpararattaṃ bodhipakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ, bhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharissāmā’ti.
an6.17:5.2.eng: ‘We will guard our sense doors, eat in moderation, be dedicated to wakefulness, discern skillful qualities, and pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn.’

an6.170-649:1.26.eng: these six things should be developed.”

an6.170-649:1.27.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an6.170-649:1.28.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an6.170-649:1.28.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an6.170-649:1.30.eng: The Book of the Sixes is finished.

an6.18:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
an6.18:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

an6.18:1.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā addhānamaggappaṭipanno aññatarasmiṃ padese macchikaṃ macchabandhaṃ macche vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamānaṃ.
an6.18:1.2.eng: While walking along the road he saw a fish dealer in a certain spot selling fish that he had killed himself.

an6.18:1.3.pli: Disvā maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an6.18:1.3.eng: Seeing this he left the road, sat at the root of a tree on the seat spread out,

an6.18:1.5.pli: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, amuṃ macchikaṃ macchabandhaṃ macche vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamānan”ti?
an6.18:1.5.eng: “Mendicants, do you see that fish dealer selling fish that he killed himself?”

an6.18:2.2.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.18:2.2.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.18:2.3.pli: ‘macchiko macchabandho macche vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’”ti?
an6.18:2.3.eng: of a fish dealer selling fish that he killed himself who, by means of that work and livelihood, got to travel by elephant, horse, chariot, or vehicle, or to enjoy wealth, or to live off a large fortune?”

an6.18:2.6.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.18:2.6.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.18:2.7.pli: ‘macchiko macchabandho macche vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’ti.

an6.18:2.9.pli: Te hi so, bhikkhave, macche vajjhe vadhāyupanīte pāpakena manasānupekkhati, tasmā so neva hatthiyāyī hoti na assayāyī na rathayāyī na yānayāyī na bhogabhogī, na mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an6.18:2.9.eng: Because when the fish are led to the slaughter he regards them with bad intentions.

an6.18:3.2.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.18:3.2.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.18:3.3.pli: ‘goghātako gāvo vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’”ti?
an6.18:3.3.eng: of a butcher of cattle selling cattle that he killed himself who, by means of that work and livelihood, got to travel by elephant, horse, chariot, or vehicle, or to enjoy wealth, or to live off a large fortune?”

an6.18:3.6.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.18:3.6.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.18:3.7.pli: ‘goghātako gāvo vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’ti.

an6.18:3.9.pli: Te hi so, bhikkhave, gāvo vajjhe vadhāyupanīte pāpakena manasānupekkhati, tasmā so neva hatthiyāyī hoti na assayāyī na rathayāyī na yānayāyī na bhogabhogī, na mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an6.18:3.9.eng: Because when the cattle are led to the slaughter he regards them with bad intentions.

an6.18:4.2.pli: api nu tumhehi diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā:
an6.18:4.2.eng: Have you ever seen or heard

an6.18:4.6.pli: māgaviko mage vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’”ti?
an6.18:4.6.eng: or a deer-hunter selling deer which he killed himself who, by means of that work and livelihood, got to travel by elephant, horse, chariot, or vehicle, or to enjoy wealth, or to live off a large fortune?”

an6.18:4.9.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ:
an6.18:4.9.eng: I too have never seen or heard of such a thing.

an6.18:4.10.pli: ‘māgaviko mage vadhitvā vadhitvā vikkiṇamāno tena kammena tena ājīvena hatthiyāyī vā assayāyī vā rathayāyī vā yānayāyī vā bhogabhogī vā mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasanto’ti.

an6.18:4.12.pli: Te hi so, bhikkhave, mage vajjhe vadhāyupanīte pāpakena manasānupekkhati, tasmā so neva hatthiyāyī hoti na assayāyī na rathayāyī na yānayāyī na bhogabhogī, na mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an6.18:4.12.eng: Because when the deer are led to the slaughter he regards them with bad intentions.

an6.18:4.13.pli: Te hi nāma so, bhikkhave, tiracchānagate pāṇe vajjhe vadhāyupanīte pāpakena manasānupekkhamāno neva hatthiyāyī bhavissati na assayāyī na rathayāyī na yānayāyī na bhogabhogī, na mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ ajjhāvasissati.
an6.18:4.13.eng: By regarding even animals led to the slaughter with bad intentions he did not get to travel by elephant, horse, chariot, or vehicle, or to enjoy wealth, or to live off a large fortune.

an6.18:4.14.pli: Ko pana vādo yaṃ manussabhūtaṃ vajjhaṃ vadhāyupanītaṃ pāpakena manasānupekkhati.
an6.18:4.14.eng: How much worse is someone who regards human beings brought to the slaughter with bad intentions!

an6.18:4.15.pli: Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
an6.18:4.15.eng: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.

an6.18:4.16.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.
an6.18:4.16.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.”

an6.19:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
an6.19:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.

an6.19:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an6.19:1.6.pli: “maraṇassati, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an6.19:1.6.eng: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It has freedom from death as its objective and culmination.

an6.19:1.7.eng: But do you develop mindfulness of death?”

an6.19:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.19:2.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

an6.19:2.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:2.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:2.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ rattindivaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:2.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live for another day and night, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:2.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:3.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an6.19:3.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:3.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:3.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:3.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ divasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:3.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live for another day, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:3.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:4.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an6.19:4.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:4.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:4.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:4.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:4.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to eat a meal of almsfood, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:4.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:4.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:5.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an6.19:5.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:5.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:5.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:5.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ cattāro pañca ālope saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:5.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to chew and swallow four or five mouthfuls, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:5.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:5.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:6.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an6.19:6.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:6.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:6.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:6.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekaṃ ālopaṃ saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:6.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to chew and swallow a single mouthful, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:6.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:6.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:7.1.eng: Another mendicant said to the Buddha,

an6.19:7.2.eng: “Sir, I too develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:7.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhāvesi maraṇassatin”ti?
an6.19:7.3.eng: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”

an6.19:7.5.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ assasitvā vā passasāmi passasitvā vā assasāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:7.5.eng: ‘Oh, if I’d only live as long as it takes to breathe out after breathing in, or to breathe in after breathing out, I’d focus on the Buddha’s instructions and I could really achieve a lot.’

an6.19:7.6.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhāvemi maraṇassatin”ti.
an6.19:7.6.eng: That’s how I develop mindfulness of death.”

an6.19:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
an6.19:8.1.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to those mendicants:

an6.19:8.2.pli: “yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:
an6.19:8.2.eng: “As to the mendicants who develop mindfulness of death by wishing

an6.19:8.3.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ rattindivaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:8.3.eng: to live for a day and night …

an6.19:9.1.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an6.19:9.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ divasaṃ jīveyyaṃ, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:9.2.eng: or to live for a day …

an6.19:10.1.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an6.19:10.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekapiṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:10.2.eng: or to live as long as it takes to eat a meal of almsfood …

an6.19:11.1.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an6.19:11.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ cattāro pañca ālope saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:11.2.eng: or to live as long as it takes to chew and swallow four or five mouthfuls—

an6.19:12.1.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, bhikkhū pamattā viharanti dandhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāventi āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an6.19:12.1.eng: these are called mendicants who live negligently. They slackly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.

an6.19:13.1.pli: Yo ca khvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:
an6.19:13.1.eng: But as to the mendicants who develop mindfulness of death by wishing

an6.19:13.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ ekaṃ ālopaṃ saṅkhāditvā ajjhoharāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:13.2.eng: to live as long as it takes to chew and swallow a single mouthful …

an6.19:14.1.pli: Yo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāveti:

an6.19:14.2.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ tadantaraṃ jīveyyaṃ yadantaraṃ assasitvā vā passasāmi passasitvā vā assasāmi, bhagavato sāsanaṃ manasi kareyyaṃ, bahu vata me kataṃ assā’ti.
an6.19:14.2.eng: or to live as long as it takes to breathe out after breathing in, or to breathe in after breathing out—

an6.19:15.1.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, bhikkhū appamattā viharanti tikkhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāventi āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an6.19:15.1.eng: these are called mendicants who live diligently. They keenly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.

an6.19:16.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an6.19:16.2.pli: ‘appamattā viharissāma, tikkhaṃ maraṇassatiṃ bhāvessāma āsavānaṃ khayāyā’ti.
an6.19:16.2.eng: ‘We will live diligently. We will keenly develop mindfulness of death for the ending of defilements.’
